image.altText: Derek Balogh

items.synopsis: He calls himself an advocate, charges for advice on fines and council rates and makes incredible claims about his success in courtrooms around Australia. But Derek Balogh has left a trail of failed cases in his wake.

title.children: This man advises his clients that elections, rates and mortgages are invalid

image.altText: young person with smoke coming out of their mouth after vaping

items.synopsis: The sale of vapes for recreational use will be banned and all other forms will be strictly controlled as the governments fights against what Health Minister Mark Butler describes as an attempt by Big Tobacco to create a new generation of nicotine addicts.

title.children: Recreational vaping to be banned, all e-cigarettes to be strictly controlled

image.altText: A woman standing on the doorframe of her van, next to a Welcome to Broome sign.

items.synopsis: A police officer of 17 years, Keely Allport diverted travel plans through the Kimberley after a break-in left her feeling traumatised.

title.children: Police officer holidaying in WA's Kimberley says she's never experienced crime like it

image.altText: Raeleen sits with her three grandkids - a little girl wearing pink and two boys in T-shirts - out the front of their house.

items.synopsis: Nearly three-quarters of Australians expect child poverty to worsen this year and say cost-of-living pressures are having a greater impact than the pandemic, according to a long-running survey released exclusively to ABC News.

title.children: Selling the furniture and couch-surfing: Families forced to make 'impossible' decisions amid fears inflation crisis hitting kids

image.altText: A soldier fires an RPG from inside a trench amid tree branches. Fire coming out of the RPG launcher

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: US updates Russian death toll in Ukraine, Twitter glitch logs users out. Catch up with The Loop

schema.headline: The Loop live: Non-prescription vapes to be banned, the search for a Texas gunman enters its third day, and historic TV props up for auction

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Treasurer doesn't rule out JobSeeker lift for people over 55
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's the latest on JobSeeker payments from political reporter Jake Evans, after some media outlets reported the payment would be lifted for people over 55 in next week's federal budget. The federal treasurer has refused to confirm whether JobSeeker payments for people over 55 will be lifted for the first time in a decade. Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers said unemployed women over 55 were the most vulnerable cohort in Australian society and the government wanted to introduce specific measures to help them. But he did not rule out the change, saying instead those details would be confirmed next week. The federal government has been under pressure to lift JobSeeker, including from its own backbench. You can keep reading Jake's story below:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The Met Gala has begun!
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: New York City's Met Gala, which I mentioned, earlier has now kicked off. This year's fashion night-of-nights will be hosted by actor Penélope Cruz, writer and actor Michaela Coel, tennis legend Roger Federer, and singer Dua Lipa. You can follow all of the latest looks and news in my colleague Jess's live blog, below:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Minister says new messaging system will make sure Australians get emergency alerts
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The federal government is set to roll out a state-of the-art National Messaging System that can send emergency warnings straight to your mobile phone, as part of next week's budget. A further $10.1 million will be put towards improving the communications network used by first responders. Emergency Services Minister Murray Watt tells ABC News Breakfast that people in disaster areas say they hadn't received emergency messages quickly enough in the past. "In some case they're sent to the wrong area. They might have the wrong phone provider and then not receive a message," he says. "So that's what this national messaging system is all about — having one system across the country that can effectively override a mobile phone system and deliver people very targetted, very quick messages." The government says the emergency messages will be easy to tell apart from scam messages. You can read more about the plan for the National Messaging System, below.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Fatalities reported after multiple car crashes during US dust storm
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Police in the US state of Illinois say a number of people have been killed and dozens of others have been injured in car crashes along a highway during a dust storm. Illinois State Police says about 40 to 60 passenger cars and several trucks were involved in the crashes. It says about 30 people have been transported to local hospitals with injuries.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ADF reportedly promised $400m for retention bonuses
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Australian Associated Press (AAP) reports that Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel could be up for a $50,000 cash bonus under a federal government push to expand the size of the nation's military. The AAP says the Albanese government will announce it has set aside $400 million for retention bonuses to help reduce the thousands of personnel leaving the armed forces. Permanent ADF members will supposedly be eligible to receive a $50,000 bonus payment near the end of their initial mandatory period of service, if they commit to the military for another three years. Under the scheme, 3,400 personnel will be able to benefit within the first three years. The government has identified ­recruitment and retention of personnel as an immediate priority in response to the defence strategic review.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Coming up: The RBA will make its latest rate decision
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Reserve Bank will weigh up later today whether to resume interest rate rises or continue its recent pause in the official cash rate. The RBA kept the cash rate at 3.6 per cent in April after 10 hikes in a row to tame inflation. Consumer prices rose 7 per cent over the year to March, down from 7.8 per cent — but that's still higher than the RBA's 2 to 3 per cent target. RBA Governor Philip Lowe has not ruled out further rate hikes. The market is predicting that rates will likely remain on hold when the RBA board makes its announcement at 2:30pm today, but it's not official until it's official.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Twitter is having issues again, and keeps logging people out
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you're noticing anything strange on Twitter this morning — don't worry, you're not alone. Many users (myself included) appear to have been logged out of their accounts on desktop, and can't log back in. Others appear to be able to briefly log in, before being kicked out again. "Twitter keeps logging me out on the web immediately after I sign in. I have tried using my three accounts on different browsers and the result is the same," one user writes on Reddit. Here's how reports of Twitter issues have looked over the past 24 hours, according to Downdetector: Twitter and its CEO Elon Musk are yet to comment on the apparent glitch. The social media platform appears to be working as normal for most people on their mobile devices, luckily. Are you having any issues with Twitter? Let me know in the comments.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US says 20,000 Russians have been killed in Ukraine war since December
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The White House says it now estimates that since December more than 20,000 Russians have been killed as Ukraine rebuffs a heavy assault by Russian forces in eastern Ukraine. White House National Security Council spokesman John Kirby says the US estimate is based on newly declassified American intelligence. US General Mark Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said in November that Russia had suffered well over 100,000 killed or wounded in the first eight months of the war. The new figures suggest that Russian losses have dramatically accelerated in recent months. The fiercest recent battles in Ukraine have been in the eastern Donetsk region, where Russia is struggling to encircle the city of Bakhmut.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Aerosmith announce farewell tour, but no Australian dates
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: US rockers Aerosmith have announced their farewell tour after 50-plus years together, but Australia has missed out (so far). The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame band have announced the dates for their Peace Out farewell tour, which begins in September and includes 40 shows across the US and Canada. "I think it's about time," guitarist Joe Perry said in an interview with The Associated Press. Perry believes the time to say goodbye is now, especially with every founding band member over the age of 70. Frontman Steven Tyler, 75, is the oldest in the group. "It's kind of a chance to celebrate the 50 years we've been out here," Perry said. "You never know how much longer everybody's going to be healthy to do this. … It's been a while since we've actually done a real tour. We did that run in Vegas, which was great. It was fun, but (we're) kind of anxious to get back on the road."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Ban on non-prescription vapes to be announced today
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Health Minister Mark Butler is expected to today unveil a plan to stamp out the growing black market for illegal vaping. The Government will allocate $234 million in next week's budget to reduce harm caused by tobacco and vaping products, including to stop the importation of non-prescription vapes. Under the changes, all general practitioners will be able to prescribe flavour-free, plain packaged vapes to patients working to quit smoking. Speaking on Q & A last night, Butler said easy access to vapes had created a new generation of nicotine addicts. "This is now the number one behavioural issue in high schools and it's rapidly becoming a serious behavioural issue in primary schools," he said. "This is a very serious problem we're facing and it has exploded over the last few years. While we were focused on the pandemic, it has utterly exploded and we've got to deal with it now." Butler is expected to further detail the government's plans during a speech at the National Press Club from 12:30pm today .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Search for Texas gunman who killed five neighbours enters third day
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The search for a gunman who fatally shot five neighbours with an AR-style rifle in the US state of Texas has entered a third day, after authorities expanded their search over the weekend while acknowledging they had little sense of the killer's possible whereabouts. On Monday, a heavy presence of police converged in an area where police had reported a possible sighting of the suspect, but later 38-year-old Francisco Oropeza wasn't found despite a search by officers, scent-tracking dogs and aerial police. The false alarm was one of the first times since Friday's shooting in the rural town of Cleveland that authorities had announced a possible sighting of Oropeza. By Sunday evening, authorities said more than 250 officers from multiple jurisdictions had joined the search, and Texas Governor Greg Abbott put up $US50,000 ($75,000) in reward money for tips leading to Oropeza's capture. "I can tell you right now, we have zero leads," said James Smith, the FBI special agent in charge.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: News Australia is searching for: Met Gala 2023
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Celebrities are hitting up New York City's Metropolitan Museum of Art today for the annual charity night and fashion event known as the Met Gala. This year's theme is Karl Lagerfeld: A Line of Beauty, paying tribute to the German fashion designer who died in 2019 — a theme which has proven to be controversial. Today's red carpet is expected to start live streaming at 8am AEST on Vogue's social media accounts. We will also be live blogging the event in a separate blog, so keep an eye out for that. You can read more about this year's Met Gala at the link below.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: One more thing: Props from shows like Breaking Bad, Cheers and I Dream of Jeannie are up for auction
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you've ever wanted to own a piece of television history, keep your eye out for a major auction coming up in the US from collector James Comisar. A number of props, sets and costumes from beloved television shows will be sold in early June — from the bar where Sam Malone greeted customers on Cheers, to the pink outfit Barbara Eden wore in I Dream of Jeannie, to props used on the set of Breaking Bad. Other items up for auction include a tunic worn by Superman in the 1950s TV series, barware from Mad Men, and costumes from Star Trek. Comisar had dreamed of creating a museum to house his collection, but when that failed to come together, he decided it was time the items leave the temperature-controlled warehouses where he's been caring for them. "I just decided these pieces should go back to the fans and let them enjoy them and then when that good day comes when a TV museum is effectuated, these pieces will be well cared for in the hands of passionate fans and collectors," he said.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: The Loop live: Non-prescription vapes to be banned, the search for a Texas gunman enters its third day, and historic TV props up for auction

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you've ever wanted to own a piece of television history, keep your eye out for a major auction coming up in the US from collector James Comisar. A number of props, sets and costumes from beloved television shows will be sold in early June — from the bar where Sam Malone greeted customers on Cheers, to the pink outfit Barbara Eden wore in I Dream of Jeannie, to props used on the set of Breaking Bad. Other items up for auction include a tunic worn by Superman in the 1950s TV series, barware from Mad Men, and costumes from Star Trek. Comisar had dreamed of creating a museum to house his collection, but when that failed to come together, he decided it was time the items leave the temperature-controlled warehouses where he's been caring for them. "I just decided these pieces should go back to the fans and let them enjoy them and then when that good day comes when a TV museum is effectuated, these pieces will be well cared for in the hands of passionate fans and collectors," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: One more thing: Props from shows like Breaking Bad, Cheers and I Dream of Jeannie are up for auction

props.alt: Gloves next to a large scale on a bench. On the scale is a plastic ziplock bag containing pills. Beakers are placed near the scale

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Police in the US state of Illinois say a number of people have been killed and dozens of others have been injured in car crashes along a highway during a dust storm. Illinois State Police says about 40 to 60 passenger cars and several trucks were involved in the crashes. It says about 30 people have been transported to local hospitals with injuries.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fatalities reported after multiple car crashes during US dust storm

props.alt: A photo of the back of a truck on a highway during a dust storm. Other trucks and cars on a road just beyond a patch of grass

children.content: (Reuters: Instagram / leylaruinseverything)
Police in the US state of Illinois say
a number of people have been killed and dozens of others have been injured
in car crashes along a highway during a dust storm.
Illinois State Police says about
40 to 60 passenger cars and several trucks
were involved in the crashes.
It says about 30 people have been transported to local hospitals with injuries.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank will weigh up later today whether to resume interest rate rises or continue its recent pause in the official cash rate. The RBA kept the cash rate at 3.6 per cent in April after 10 hikes in a row to tame inflation. Consumer prices rose 7 per cent over the year to March, down from 7.8 per cent — but that's still higher than the RBA's 2 to 3 per cent target. RBA Governor Philip Lowe has not ruled out further rate hikes. The market is predicting that rates will likely remain on hold when the RBA board makes its announcement at 2:30pm today, but it's not official until it's official.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coming up: The RBA will make its latest rate decision

props.alt: A wall outside the Reserve Bank of Australia, showing the building name. Two people walk nearby

children.content: (ABC News: Michael Janda)
The Reserve Bank will weigh up later today
whether to resume interest rate rises or continue its recent pause
in the official cash rate.
The RBA kept the cash rate at 3.6 per cent in April after 10 hikes in a row to tame inflation.
Consumer prices rose 7 per cent over the year to March, down from 7.8 per cent — but that's still higher than the RBA's 2 to 3 per cent target.
RBA Governor Philip Lowe has not ruled out further rate hikes.
The market is predicting that rates will likely remain on hold when
the RBA board makes its announcement at 2:30pm today
, but it's not official until it's official.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're noticing anything strange on Twitter this morning — don't worry, you're not alone. Many users (myself included) appear to have been logged out of their accounts on desktop, and can't log back in. Others appear to be able to briefly log in, before being kicked out again. "Twitter keeps logging me out on the web immediately after I sign in. I have tried using my three accounts on different browsers and the result is the same," one user writes on Reddit. Here's how reports of Twitter issues have looked over the past 24 hours, according to Downdetector: Twitter and its CEO Elon Musk are yet to comment on the apparent glitch. The social media platform appears to be working as normal for most people on their mobile devices, luckily. Are you having any issues with Twitter? Let me know in the comments.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Twitter is having issues again, and keeps logging people out

Others appear to be able to briefly log in, before being kicked out again.

The social media platform appears to be working as normal for most people on their mobile devices, luckily.
Are you having any issues with Twitter?
Let me know in the comments.

image.altText: A chef holds up plates of food.

items.synopsis: Scottish-born Jock Zonfrillo — who died in Melbourne — is being remembered as an "incredible chef" who was loved in and outside of the kitchen.

title.children: Jock Zonfrillo remembered as an 'incredible chef' and influential member of Australia's culinary landscape

image.altText: A close up of a couple in their twenties. Their faces are bathed in blue light. They are smiling.

items.synopsis: Two women and a teenage girl were killed in a crash involving an allegedly stolen car driven by a 13-year-old in Maryborough on Sunday night as police investigations into the incident continue.

title.children: 'Until we meet in heaven': Maryborough community comes to grips with triple fatality as loved ones remembered

image.altText: A drone shot of a regional suburb with houses and trees and playgrounds

items.synopsis: Against all logic and decades of previous experience, housing prices appear to have not just stabilised but turned the corner, writes Ian Verrender. This isn't supposed to be happening.

title.children: Perfect storm brewing for housing market and it could make buying your own home a pipedream

image.altText: A man in a broad-brimmed hat, shirt and shorts sits on a rock outcrop, an outback river, plains and range in the distance.

items.synopsis: Fossils billions of years old that show evidence of some of the first signs of life on Earth have been nominated for a national heritage listing.

title.children: Push to protect Pilbara rocks that could help determine if there was ever life on Mars

image.altText: People walking past the outside of the Reserve Bank of Australia in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Banks and financial markets are predicting the RBA will keep the cash rate on hold at 3.6 per cent for another month at today's meeting, with the ASX set to open lower. Follow the day's events with our live blog.

title.children: Reserve Bank tipped to leave interest rates on hold for a second month, ASX to open lower

schema.headline: Live updates: Reserve Bank tipped to pause interest rates for another month, ASX to open lower, JPMorgan Chase buys First Republic

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Could the government see a budget surplus by the end of the year?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's certainly the optimistic forecasts by some, including independent economist Chris Richardson. He believes there's a chance of seeing a "wafer thin" surplus over the year to March, which would put treasurer Jim Chalmers in sight of the first budget surplus Australia has seen in 15 years. What's behind this potential surplus? Commodity prices, in particular booming iron ore and thermal coal prices. But that's not to say deficits will be a thing of the past — as senior business correspondent Peter Ryan explains in the clip below 👇

liveBlogUpdate.headline: House prices haven't just stabilised — they've turned the corner
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: CoreLogic data released yesterday show house prices have rebounded from their downturn, rising for a second consecutive month. Every capital city, with the exception of Darwin, saw a rise in real estate prices, led by Sydney. Regional areas also saw some minor gains. But against all logic and what previous experience has shown us, house prices appear to have not just stabilised but turned a corner. You can read more of this analysis by business editor Ian Verrender below 👇

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX set to slip as Reserve Bank rates decision looms
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good morning, it's Tuesday May 2 and you've found yourself on the ABC's markets and business blog — and what a day we have in front of us. Let's get the elephant in the room out of the way first: it's rates day. The RBA is meeting today to decide what to do with the cash rate, after leaving rates on hold at 3.6% in April. But we know that was a lineball call — in the meeting minutes published a couple of weeks later, the RBA board had considered another rise of 0.25 percentage points. So what could today's decision look like? Major banks and investors are widely predicting the RBA will leave the cash rate unchanged at 3.6%, with data last week showing inflation is slowly coming down. I'll bring you the latest on that decision when it happens at 2:30pm AEST, and all the reaction that follows. On the markets front, the Australian share market is looking to open lower this morning after ASX futures were down -0.7% to 7,336 points as of 7:30am. It follows a mixed performance on Wall Street overnight, with US financial markets largely dominated by the news that regulators had seized First Republic, before selling its assets to JPMorgan Chase to fight off another global banking crisis. First Republic is the third US bank to collapse in just two months, after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank folded earlier this year. All in all, there's a bit on — pour yourself a coffee and let's see where the day takes us.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Live updates: Reserve Bank tipped to pause interest rates for another month, ASX to open lower, JPMorgan Chase buys First Republic

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ASX SPI 200 futures : -0.7% to 7,336 Australian dollar : 66.28 US cents On Wall St: Dow -0.1%, S & P 500 -0.4%, Nasdaq -0.1% In Europe: Stoxx +0.1%, FTSE +0.5%, DAX +0.8% Spot gold: -0.4% at $US1,982.05/ounce Brent crude: -1.2% at $US79.40/barrel Iron ore: -0.1% at $US101.90 a tonne Bitcoin: +1.2% at $US27,986

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's certainly the optimistic forecasts by some, including independent economist Chris Richardson. He believes there's a chance of seeing a "wafer thin" surplus over the year to March, which would put treasurer Jim Chalmers in sight of the first budget surplus Australia has seen in 15 years. What's behind this potential surplus? Commodity prices, in particular booming iron ore and thermal coal prices. But that's not to say deficits will be a thing of the past — as senior business correspondent Peter Ryan explains in the clip below 👇
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Could the government see a budget surplus by the end of the year?

Chris Richardson

first budget surplus Australia has seen in 15 years

iron ore
and

prices.
But that's not to say deficits will be a thing of the past — as

explains in the clip below

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: CoreLogic data released yesterday show house prices have rebounded from their downturn, rising for a second consecutive month. Every capital city, with the exception of Darwin, saw a rise in real estate prices, led by Sydney. Regional areas also saw some minor gains. But against all logic and what previous experience has shown us, house prices appear to have not just stabilised but turned a corner. You can read more of this analysis by business editor Ian Verrender below 👇
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: House prices haven't just stabilised — they've turned the corner

featuredLink.title: Perfect storm brewing for housing market and it could make buying your own home a pipedream

children.content: CoreLogic data released yesterday show house prices have rebounded from their downturn, rising for a second consecutive month.
Every capital city, with the exception of Darwin, saw a rise in real estate prices, led by Sydney. Regional areas also saw some minor gains.
But against all logic and what previous experience has shown us, house prices appear to have not just stabilised but turned a corner.
You can read more of this analysis by
business editor Ian Verrender
below

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, it's Tuesday May 2 and you've found yourself on the ABC's markets and business blog — and what a day we have in front of us. Let's get the elephant in the room out of the way first: it's rates day. The RBA is meeting today to decide what to do with the cash rate, after leaving rates on hold at 3.6% in April. But we know that was a lineball call — in the meeting minutes published a couple of weeks later, the RBA board had considered another rise of 0.25 percentage points. So what could today's decision look like? Major banks and investors are widely predicting the RBA will leave the cash rate unchanged at 3.6%, with data last week showing inflation is slowly coming down. I'll bring you the latest on that decision when it happens at 2:30pm AEST, and all the reaction that follows. On the markets front, the Australian share market is looking to open lower this morning after ASX futures were down -0.7% to 7,336 points as of 7:30am. It follows a mixed performance on Wall Street overnight, with US financial markets largely dominated by the news that regulators had seized First Republic, before selling its assets to JPMorgan Chase to fight off another global banking crisis. First Republic is the third US bank to collapse in just two months, after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank folded earlier this year. All in all, there's a bit on — pour yourself a coffee and let's see where the day takes us.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX set to slip as Reserve Bank rates decision looms

image.altText: Illustration of a woman looking at the reflection of her face in red wine

items.synopsis: Clare started using alcohol to feel better when life became difficult. She almost lost everything she cared about but eventually she found her way back to happiness.

title.children: Clare desperately wanted to stop drinking but she couldn't make it stick. Then her family intervened

image.altText: A selfie of a woman and man in beanie in front of blue van

items.synopsis: Rachel Lehmann Ware and her husband, Duncan, made a chaotic escape from Ukraine with their three cats after the Russian invasion last year. Now the Tasmanian teachers have returned to Kyiv, where lessons are often taught in an air raid shelter.

title.children: A year ago, this Australian couple fled Ukraine with their three cats. Now they're back in Kyiv

image.altText: Talou Kesia

items.synopsis: After a string of shark attacks, New Caledonia's government closed Nouméa's beaches for a year. But locals say it has gone too far.

title.children: Nouméa is an island paradise — but for the next year you're not allowed to swim

image.altText: A sign sits outside Launceston General Hospital.

items.synopsis: A coroner lashes the Launceston General Hospital for not following its procedures and causing delays in diagnosing a baby's bowel obstruction, saying it was the "difference between her survival and death".

title.children: Baby with bowel obstruction died after hospital's failures, coroner finds

image.altText: Two women sit beside each other on a bench. One woman has her arm around the other's shoulders.

items.synopsis: Desley Ketchup believes her son might still be alive if police had let her or his siblings speak to him during a siege. WARNING: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised this article contains images and names of people who have died.

title.children: Family of man shot dead by police question why they weren't called in to help

image.altText: A apir of mailboxes. One red, one yellow.

items.synopsis: Mail posted in November finally arrives in a rural Queensland town that was isolated by flooding, with local leaders calling for urgent road upgrades and Australia Post to improve its services.

title.children: Christmas presents, mail turns up in April as outback residents feel like they live in 'third world country'

image.altText: An empty school corridor.

items.synopsis: The woman was aged in her 30s a decade ago when she was a physical education teacher at the school, where the teenage girl was a student.

title.children: Female teacher admits sexual offences against teen student, fights 10 other charges

image.altText: Kittens waiting to be adopted inside a cage.

items.synopsis: Pets are being surrendered across the country at an alarming rate, and with interest in adoptions waning, animal shelters are struggling to accommodate the influx of animals.

title.children: 'Longest-ever backlog': Animal shelters are overflowing as pet surrenders reach all-time high

image.altText: A man in a red Adventure Kokoda t-shirt speaking into a walkie talkie

items.synopsis: A major route into the Kokoda Track in Papua New Guinea's Central Province appears to be blockaded, amid a feud between a trekking operator and the track's managing authority.

title.children: Major route into the Kokoda track appears to have been blockaded amid tour operator feud

image.altText: A sketched image of a court setting features a man in a suit in the foreground and a judge and lady on the stand,

items.synopsis: US District Judge Lewis Kaplan denies a motion for mistrial after Donald Trump's lawyer accuses him of being biased against the former president, including in the jury's presence.

title.children: Donald Trump denied mistrial in rape case brought by writer E Jean Carroll

image.altText: A wooden thrown with a stone placed under the seat.

items.synopsis: An ancient and controversial block of stone has made the journey from Edinburgh Castle to London for the coronation of King Charles III.

title.children: What is the Stone of Destiny and why is it needed for the King's coronation?

image.altText: debris can be seen on the ground in a residential area after a military strike

items.synopsis: Russian strikes injure dozens despite Ukrainian air defence crews managing to destroy most of the missiles launched on the country early on Monday morning.

title.children: 34 injured and houses destroyed after Russia launches early morning strikes on Ukraine

image.altText: Child's hand clasping adult male finger, close up.

items.synopsis: A former UK crime analyst was so stunned by the prevalence of child sexual abuse in Australia that he studied perpetrators' character traits in an effort to better educate authorities and parents.

title.children: The common traits shared by some of Queensland's most prolific sex offenders

image.altText: a trader wearing glasses works at the post where First Republic stock is traded at the NYSE

items.synopsis: US regional bank First Republic had a little more than $301 billion worth of assets and around 7,000 employees.

title.children: US authorities 'auction' First Republic Bank after second biggest bank failure in history

image.altText: A fire burns beyond a mountain range.

items.synopsis: The new system would let the government instantly message all mobiles in a defined area — stopping them from being overlooked or dismissed by those in danger.

title.children: 'Every second is critical': Major upgrade to national emergency messages to receive more than $10m

image.altText: A tattooed middle-aged white man wearing a grey polo shirt, jeans and a bandanna sits in front of motel wall.

items.synopsis: Almost three months after a Norfolk Southern train derailment blackened the skies and sent residents fleeing, residents of East Palestine, Ohio say they are still unsure how to move on.

title.children: 'No idea how long we can continue': East Palestine families still living in limbo, months after fiery train wreck

image.altText: Smoke rises from buildings in the city of Khartoum, where a man can be seen in the foreground walking on the ground.

items.synopsis: It is estimated some 73,000 people have already fled to Sudan's neighbouring countries.

title.children: Sudan humanitarian crisis turning into a 'full-blown catastrophe', UN says

image.altText: A car billows with fire and thick, black smoke in a parking lot during protests in France.

items.synopsis: May Day traditionally sees large rallies, but unions are expecting hundreds of thousands of people to turn out this year as anger against pension reform continues.

title.children: Violence and chaos erupt at the May Day labour union march in Paris

image.altText: A close up of Kendall smiling tightly on stage with a twinkle in his eye.

items.synopsis: The Roys search for the fountain of youth and a new vision for Waystar's future. But Kendall has a gleam in his eye, which can only mean one thing.

title.children: Succession recap: Is it too soon to say we've reached peak Kendall?

image.altText: Steph Catley challenges Svenja Huth during Champions League semifinal

items.synopsis: A severely depleted Arsenal side goes down 3-2 in extra time of the second leg of their semifinal against Wolfsburg, ending the campaign of Matildas star Steph Catley, with Caitlin Foord sidelined by injury.

title.children: Catley and Foord out of Champions League final after Wolfsburg beat Arsenal in extra time

image.altText: A man raises a hand while performing a dance move.

items.synopsis: Ian Smith, the husband of former Democrats leader Natasha Stott Despoja, busted out the move in front of an audience including Julie Bishop, Malcolm Turnbull and Hollywood A-listers Kate Beckinsale, Sienna Miller and Kate Moss at a gala dinner in New York last week.

title.children: 'The worm goes global': Rita Ora wowed by Adelaide lobbyist's dancefloor moves
